titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to C. L. Hinkle, June 4, 1901
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Envelope and typewritten letter; handwritten WFC signature and initials, with a few typed words showing handwritten corrections. The letter date may have been incorrectly typed; the envelope is dated June 3rd, 1901; BBWW performed in Pottsville, Pennsylvania, on June 3, 1901. Curtis L. Hinkle was clerk of the Wyoming State Land Board in Cheyenne and friend to WFC. Charles DeMaris (1833-1914) discovered and developed the hot springs on the western edge of Cody, Wyoming, known as DeMaris Springs. William Alford Richards (1849-1912) was the 4th governor of Wyoming (1895-1899) and Assistant Commissioner of the General Land Office (U.S.) during 1901.

div1.p: I wrote you some time ago that I wanted to put in an application for some of the waters of those mineral springs to be used for the benefit of humanity.2 The cost of the work to make those waters available to mankind will be enormous and until this money is spent no benefit of any magnitude can come to the public from these waters. I now have surveyors an and draughtsmen at work near there on the Cody & Salsbury canal that I can have make plans, maps &c for the State officials that cannot fail to convince them that it is for the benefit of the whole public that these springs be given over to capital that will improve them and bring within the reach of the public their health giving qualities. As the waters are now they can only be of use to a very few at any season of the year while in May, June and July they are unaccessableunaccessible, being covered by the river. There are no accomodationsaccommodations for the public so that from November to March they are again not accessableaccessible. Please see officials and let me know.

postscript.p: P S When I was in Washington W. A. Richards told me the segregation papers for the land under the Cody & Sal sburySalsbury canal would be ready in sixty days.3 What do you know about this?

back.note: Note 1: Although this letter is dated June 4, 1901, the postmark is for June 3. Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed at Pottsville, Pennsylvania, on June 3.
Note 2: William F. Cody wrote several letters to Hinkle in 1901 in an unsuccessful effort to obtain water rights at DeMaris Springs.
Note 3: Former Wyoming governor W. A. Richards was then assistant commissioner of the U.S. General Land Office.
